outcome cytology within last 3 years   Results  Overall Pap screening rates 71 BRFSS 79 HINTS 66 HCPS among 41 657 740 1571 women respectively BRFSS showed women 60 64 years old aPR 0 88 95 CI 0 85 0 screening aPR 1 20 95 CI 1 13 1 28 insurance higher screening rates uninsured aPR 1 47 95 CI 1 33 1 62 HINTS HCPS also showed trends   Conclusions  All three surveys show cervical cancer screening rates women 45 65 years insufficient reduce cervical cancer incidence Insurance major positive predictor screening followed younger age education Race ethnicity variable predictors depending survey sustainability immunization registries   Abstract   Introduction  The Global Vaccine Action Plan Regional Immunization Action Plan Americas call countries improve immunization data quality Immunization information systems particularly electronic immunization registries EIRs help facilitate program management increase coverage However little known efforts develop implement systems low middle income countries We present experiences Mexico Peru implementing EIRs   Methods  We conducted case studies EIR Mexico population registry Peru Information gathered technical documents stakeholder focus groups site visits semi structured interviews national stakeholders We organized findings narratives emphasized challenges lessons learned   Results  Mexico built one world first EIRs incorporating novel features local level tracking patients however insufficient resources poor data registration practices led system discontinuation Peru created information system improve affiliation social programs including immunization program quality demographic data Mexico experience highlights lessons failed sustainability EIR laudable effort reform country information system Peru demonstrates attempts improve health data may strengthen health systems including immunization data Major challenges information system implementation sustainability Peru Mexico related funding clear governance structures resistance among health workers   Discussion  These case studies reinforce need countries ensure adequate funding plans sustainability health worker capacity building activities implementing EIRs They also suggest new approaches implementation including economic incentives sub national administrative levels opportunities link efforts improve immunization data health political priorities More information best practices needed ensure successful adoption sustainability immunization registries low middle income countries   Keywords   Electronic immunization registries   Immunization information systems   Immunization data   National immunization programs   Global vaccine action plan     1  Introduction  High quality immunization data facilitate  In 1973 Mexico established NIP 1991 became Universal Vaccination Program PVU   4  All acronyms public agencies Mexico Peru provided Spanish e g PVU  Programa Universal de Vacunación   3 1 2  Immunization information system  In 1991 Mexico established PROVAC computerized program record immunization data country health facilities including private facilities  Though official coverage rates high time concerns levels might falsely elevated During system 18 year history Mexico developed different versions PROVAC program open source changes required include eight vaccines added PVU 1991 2008  In 2013 Mexico stopped using PROVAC due coverage discrepancies The National Population Council CONAPO completed data reconciliation information National Institute Statistics Geography showed PROVAC denominators underestimated coverages thus overestimated Coverages estimated near 100 dropped around 80 e g 99 DTP3 2012 vs 83 DTP3 2013   3 1 3  Implementation challenges  PROVAC faced many challenges including accelerated inclusion new vaccines insufficient resources information technology personnel devoted system  PROVAC open coding exposed errors Between within regions users administrators created different versions system resulting inconsistencies potential data manipulation Complicating matters errors numerators denominators Denominators never validated CONAPO data numerators based distributed rather administered doses This resulted partly PROVAC design Although health workers linked administered doses patients local level system never online meaning coverage information higher levels based aggregated data prone substitute estimations e doses distributed rather doses administered   3 1 4  Lessons learned next steps  In 2013 Mexico acknowledged poor quality vaccination coverage estimates began revamp information system  Nevertheless transition difficult due challenges coordinating public private providers immunization services Mexico fragmented health system multiple providers health insurance mechanisms   3 2  Peru   3 2 1  Health system National immunization program  Peru established NIP 1979 Coverages generally high DTP3 88 95 2012 2016   3 2 2  The Padrón Nominal impact immunization data  In 2012 Peru created census database  Padrón Nominal  Three major political issues led PN creation The first longstanding problem citizens lacking representation civil registries  Developing PN required Peru evaluate birth registration practices Since 2004 ESNI used paper based registry linked MoH health target data census projections starting 2016 used birth registration systems calculate immunization coverage  To capture children without documentation MoH MEF MIDIS incentivized municipalities identify children aged 6 years areas collaboration health facilities civil registration offices The MEF required local governments capture users immunization services registries condition financing PN  From 2013 2016 incentives led widespread use  Padrón   3 2 3  Implementation challenges  Challenges implementing PN include reconciling discrepancies denominator data PN population figures vs census data difficulties connecting system nominal registries lack funding MEF 2016   3 2 4  Lessons learned next steps  Due aforementioned challenges PN remains incompletely implemented Even system capacity identify children lacking health social interventions generate useful data decision making suggests may become permanent policy tool  Padrón   4  Discussion  Extending benefits immunization people requires reliable timely immunization data  Padrón Nominal  Compared aspects NIPs low middle income countries EIRs may understudied underappreciated While sustainable funding health worker training key determinants EIR sustainability relatively little known low middle income countries sustain systems  First rationales establishing strengthening EIRs may extend beyond immunization health political priorities As immunization integrates health services governments likely support proposals multi purpose interventions The PN creation Peru supported least four governmental agencies exemplifies point Second EIR sustainability requires investment various government agencies investment might increased agency understands stands gain In Peru MEF sought better data planning purposes MoH sought higher coverages MIDIS sought equitable health outcomes In designing EIR proposals sustainability plans health officials thus consider system benefit stakeholders Third predictable funding necessary countries lacking funding likely delay implementation resources available ideally protected long term strategies clear governance structures budgets secured legislation Countries may consider innovative funding models economic incentives used Peru These models may facilitate implementation prove cost effective improve service quality  Finally EIR sustainability depends system quality adaptability Recommendations exist variables child age guiding principles entering data close vaccination possible terms time place  Several limitations acknowledged Case studies offer depth explanations complex events multiple causes criticized lacking rigor producing non generalizable results  To deliver benefits vaccination persons countries Americas WHO regions must continue improve immunization information systems Mexico Peru experiences helpful countries seeking use EIRs More information best practices lessons learned needed ensure successful implementation EIRs low middle income countries   Declaration molecular phylogeny shield bearer moth family Heliozelidae   Five major clades suggested molecular evidence   Rich undescribed species diversity prevalent southern hemisphere particularly Australia   Abstract   Heliozelidae widespread evolutionarily early diverging family small day flying monotrysian moths comprehensive phylogeny lacking We generated first molecular phylogeny family using DNA sequences two mitochondrial genes COI COII two nuclear genes H3 28S 130 Heliozelidae specimens including eight twelve known genera  Antispila  Antispilina  Coptodisca  Heliozela  Holocacista
